chapter.title: Installation
chapter.para: Game is written completely in Ruby. While Ruby is an interpreted programming language, it isn't needed (and most probably even not possible) to compile the code. You just have to install Ruby interpreter and a few libraries. Both the interpreter and all needed libraries are licensed by open source licenses and you can download them all for free.

section.title: Linux
section.para: Ruby is included in most Linux distributions, so the easiest way for you might be to install it using the package manager. Source archive (if you prefer to compile from source - e.g. your distribution doesn't contain up-to-date ruby package and you don't want to upgrade to a newer distribution) can be downloaded at .

section.title: Windows
section.para: Go to and download some of the packages marked as stable. I personally have a good experience with the "One Click Installer" - it is a regular self-extracting EXE installer which includes the interpreter, documentation, interactive shell, ri documentation browser, many useful libraries and Nice Ruby IDE.

If you are installing Ruby from the One Click Installer, you might want not to check option "Enable RubyGems" (see image below).
If you check this option, the installer appends option '-rubygems' to environment variable RUBYOPT which causes Ruby to always load RubyGems. FreeVikings before release 0.6 (and many more applications built upon the RUDL library) wouldn't work then. On the other side, you may want to check this option, because some useful libraries (such as Log4r, which is useful when you want to see detailed freeVikings debugging data) are included in the installer as gems. But even if you don't check this option, you can still use RubyGems when you need - just start ruby from the commandline with option '-rubygems':
> ruby -rubygems freevikings.rb

section.title: Libraries
section.para:
Libraries you have to install:
RUDL (get from SourceForge)
Those which should be included in Ruby distributions and you need to install them if they aren't:
REXML (usually packed with Ruby)
YAML
Optional:
Log4r (included in Ruby One-Click installer as a gem; optional since fV 0.6, get from RAA)
Redistributed with freeVikings:
script (included since fV 0.6; get from RAA in order to play older versions)

section.title: RUDL
section.para: RUDL is SDL port for Ruby.

section.title: Linux
section.para: First check you have all libraries listed below. RUDL can build even missing some of them, but it may cause situation that freeVikings won't work. The good message is, that most Linux distributions include binary packages of these libraries.

Some Linux distributions may include RUDL as a binary package, but I don't know any. So most of us have to download from SourceForge: . Download latest source package (at the time of writing of this document it was release 0.8).

Unpack downloaded RUDL archive and ener the new directory rudl-0.8
$ ruby extconf.rb
This checks for required libraries and creates Makefiles.
$ make
As superuser type
# make install
(If you needed to know how to compile and use RUDL not having access to superuser account, mail me and I will extend this manual for this case.)

section.title: Windows
section.para: Get latest windows binary package from . Usually two Windows binary archives are provided - get the one named rudl-0.x-for-ruby-1.x.x-setup-releasebuild.zip Unpack it. Execute script install-on-windows.rb . It will open shell window and ask you two questions: if it should continue installing RUDL (you want to answer 'y') and where you want additional DLLs to be put (if you don't know any better place for them, let the installer put them in your ruby/bin directory - I have them there and it works well)

section.title: REXML
section.para: REXML is a very powerful XML-processing library and (I think since ruby-1.8.2) it is distributed together with Ruby as a part of it's library. So if you installed Ruby e.g. from source or on Windows from the One-Click installer, you already have REXML.
Some Linux distro-makers like to provide it as a separate packege so look for it.

Simple test to check if REXML is present in your system:
[igneus@vidhost tmp]$ irb irb(main):001:0> require 'rexml/document' => true
Great!
irb(main):001:0> require 'rexml/document' LoadError: no such file to load -- rexml/document from (irb):1:in `require' from (irb):1
Here, unfortunatelly, you will have to try to find REXML. You can found the archive at . Unpack it and follow instructions from the file INSTALL.

section.title: YAML
section.para: I can't remember if YAML is distributed together with Ruby or not. I hope it is (I have ruby-1.9.0 source for playing and it includes YAML library), but if you get LoadError either on freeVikings start or on level loading, saying, that you haven't YAML, it's time to look for the library and send me an e-mail (Hey, your manual is incomplete!).

section.title: Log4r
section.para: Since freeVikings 0.6 you don't need this library to run freeVikings, because it is useful mainly for development and freeVikings contain a simple bypass which is used if Log4r isn't found. However, even as a non-developer, you might want this library in order to get better informed about what's happening inside freeVikings - e.g. if the game regularly crashes at startup and you want to send me a bug report.

Ruby One-Click installer contains Log4r as a gem. If you want to play freeVikings with Log4r enabled, start game from the commandline:
C:\kuba\freeVikings> ruby -rubygems freevikings.rb

It is possible to install Log4r using gems:
$ gem install log4r
(If you have problems using gems, don't ask me - I haven't solved them yet myself.) Remember that you can't use this for freeVikings before release 0.6.
The second way is to download Log4r as an archive and install it manually: get it from and follow instructions in file INSTALL.

section.title: Script
section.para: This small but great library is distributed together with freeVikings since release 0.6, but if you want to play older versions, you can get it at .

chapter.title: Running freeVikings
chapter.para: You have installed Ruby and all required libraries. Now you can try to run freeVikings. For the first time it is useful to invoke game from the command line, because if it crashes, you see the error output.

You may also want to give some arguments. Type
$ ruby freevikings --help
for full listing of supported options.

Example: disable sound (e.g. you hate freeVikings music or want to listen to your favourite mp3s while playing freeVikings).
$ ruby freevikings --sound off

Another example: Play other campaign than the Default one.
$ ruby freevikings -l locs/RubyCampaign
Look at the directory locs. Currently it contains three campaign:
DafaultCampaign - 6 levels of varying quality
RubyCampaign - one stupid, but hot-new level
TestsCampaign - 12 small stupid levels for testing of different features of the game (mainly monsters) and 2 ancient levels which I wasn't able to delete because of nostalgy

chapter.title: Game controls
chapter.para: I designed freeVikings with aim of immitating Lost Vikings where the old game was good and making it better where needed. Following this philosophy I am doing my best to copy keyboard controls inside game and add a few mouse controls (currently it is possible to use mouse for switching between vikings, selecting item inside inventory and moving items between vikings). On the other side I implemented exitting and giving up differently, because it took several minutes before I guessed how to do this in Lost Vikings.

General:
Kill game immediately: [X] button on the window
Restart level: F2
Return to menu: Esc
Pause: P
Switching between vikings:
Switch to next viking: Page Up
Switch to previous viking: right Ctrl or Page Down
Select any viking: left-click on his portrait
All three vikings:
Move left/right: cursor key left/right
Switch something on: S or cursor key up
Switch something off: F or cursor key down
Use item: E or U
Baleog (green guy):
Use sword: space
Shoot arrow: D
Erik (blue guy):
Jump: space
Olaf (yellow guy):
Change shield position: space

Maybe the most tricky thing in Lost Vikings was inventory using. In freeVikings this traditional tricky keyboard-commanded system has been preserved, but additional possibility to use mouse instead has been added.

Items are collected as vikings touch them, so you don't to bother with pushing any key to collect them. They are storted in vikings' inventories. Every inventory has four slots and if these are full, viking cannot collect any more items. To make some slots free, viking can either delete some item (which might be useful later!) or give it to any of his friends.

On the image below you can see the bottom of game screen. Active viking is Erik (his portraid is coloured - the others are black and white). The yellow frame shows which item in the inventory is active.
Press Tab. Game is paused and the yellow frame started blinking. You can use cursor keys to move yellow frame around the inventory. If you press Delete now, the active item is deleted. Press Tab again to unpause and continue playing.
You can select another item in viking's inventory also by clicking on it. Unfortunatelly deleting items using a mouse hasn't been implemented yet.

The most complicated case: you need to move one of Baleog's items to Erik. Before it is possible, all the exchange participants (Erik and Baleog in this case) must touch each other. Now press Tab (pauses game, switches to 'inventory mode') and then Space (which switches to 'items exchanging mode'). Frame in active viking's inventory is now green - see image below - and blinking. Inventories of vikings which can't participate in the exchange get darker (see Olaf's). Use cursor keys left/right to move active item between vikings. Than push Space to switch to 'normal inventory mode' again.

You can do the same - move items between vikings - also using a mouse. But it has a slight disadvantage - while this operation has no real-time visual effect, you have to check yourself that the vikings touch etc. If the item doesn't disappear from one and appear in another inventory, try again, try to move vikings, ... (or learn to use the 'keyboard way' and wait for next release with better mouse support).

chapter.title: Troubleshooting
chapter.para: While playing with freeVikings, you can encounter several kinds of problems. It is usually useful to start program from console, because code of freeVikings is full of debugging output and logging engine is set up so that it should print all important messages to the standard error output. You should also consider running freeVikings with Log4r (as discussed in )

If you encounter an error and you can't solve it yourself, you can ask me for support. Before writing an e-mail, you should
try to repeat the error and write where and in which circumstances it occurs
copy content of console (you can send it either as text or as screenshot) - error messages printed there are really valuable for me
pack content of directory freeVikings/log (e.g. as a ZIP archive or as a tarball)
I'll do my best to help you.
